TITLE: Russia and Far-Right Americans Find Common Ground With Ukraine War
SUMMARY: Some conservatives have echoed the Kremlin’s misleading claims about the war and vice versa, giving each other’s assertions a sheen of credibility.

TITLE: Yes, You Can Make Your Tech Survive Obsolescence
SUMMARY: Our gadgets eventually become outdated, but here are workarounds to keep them alive and secure past when manufacturers say.

TITLE: How 6 Workers Built New Careers In the Pandemic
SUMMARY: For some, the Covid-19 crisis presented an opportunity to change course. For each, it was a big risk on a new future.

TITLE: Renault, the biggest Western automaker in Russia, halts operations there.
SUMMARY: The French company is a partner of Russia’s top car manufacturer.

TITLE: Why This Silicon Valley Prophet Says He’s Still an Optimist
SUMMARY: Stewart Brand coined the term “personal computer” and was one of the first to envision what digital technology would become. He knows it got messy. He thinks tech can clean itself up.

TITLE: China’s Divorce Rate Is Down, but So Are Marriages
SUMMARY: While officials say a new law has helped save marriages, the bigger challenge in the country’s demographic crisis is that fewer people are getting married in the first place.

TITLE: Airlines ask Biden to end mask requirements for planes and airports.
SUMMARY: The chief executives of American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and several other passenger and cargo carriers made the request Wednesday.

TITLE: Renault Halts Operations in Russia
SUMMARY: The French company is a partner of Russia’s top car manufacturer.

TITLE: Sinovac Booster Gives Elderly Stronger Protection Against Omicron, Study Finds
SUMMARY: Given the surge of Omicron cases in Asia, the new research lends urgency to vaccination campaigns in China and Hong Kong.

TITLE: Jury Finds Former Boeing Pilot Not Guilty of Fraud in 737 Max Case
SUMMARY: The pilot, Mark Forkner, was the only person to face criminal charges for flaws that resulted in two fatal crashes of one of Boeing’s most important planes.

TITLE: NASA Plans to Give SpaceX Some Company on the Moon
SUMMARY: The agency will seek bids for future lunar landing spacecraft from companies other than SpaceX, which won the first contract to return American astronauts to the moon.

TITLE: Moderna to Seek Authorization of Its Coronavirus Vaccine for Young Children
SUMMARY: The company said the vaccine produced a strong immune response in children younger than 6, but proved only about 40 percent effective in preventing symptomatic Covid-19.

TITLE: Google Will Allow Some Apps, Starting With Spotify, to Offer Alternate Billing Methods
SUMMARY: The test program is likely to whittle away at the lucrative commissions that Google has charged app developers for money made on its platform.

TITLE: Biden Administration Will Reinstate Some Tariff Exclusions on Chinese Imports
SUMMARY: The move comes after months of complaints by business groups that the Biden administration was not doing enough to alleviate financial pain from the Trump trade war.

TITLE: John Roach, Pioneer of the Personal Computer, Is Dead at 83
SUMMARY: He helped make the home computer ubiquitous by introducing the fully assembled Tandy TRS-80, which was so novel at the time that it became a museum piece.

TITLE: With Eye to Russia, Biden Administration Asks Companies to Report Cyberattacks
SUMMARY: A new law requires companies to tell the federal government about hacks, but the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency still has to work out the details of what must be reported.

TITLE: Pfizer Recalls Some Blood Pressure Drugs, Citing Cancer Risk
SUMMARY: The move follows recalls of other medications found to have higher levels of potential carcinogens.

TITLE: Germany’s leader says a boycott of Russian energy would imperil ‘hundreds of thousands of jobs.’
SUMMARY: Germany, Europe’s largest economy, has been the most prominent opponent of a boycott of Russian energy. It relies on Russia for about 55 percent of its natural gas, 35 percent of its oil and half its coal.

TITLE: MacKenzie Scott Tallies Her Donations So Far: $12 Billion to 1,257 Groups
SUMMARY: The philanthropist announced new donations to Ukraine aid and Planned Parenthood, and said she would soon debut a database of all her giving.

TITLE: Stellantis and LG to Build Battery Plant in Ontario
SUMMARY: The automaker, which was created by the merger of Fiat Chrysler and Peugeot, has lagged in the fast-growing market for electric cars.

TITLE: She opened a restaurant in New York at the start of the pandemic. Here’s how she survived.
Janet Yellen will discuss sanctions on Russian gold with lawmakers.
SUMMARY: A proposal to target Russia’s gold reserves comes as the Biden administration looks to crack down on sanctions evasion.

TITLE: Britain Will Take Measures to Ease Inflation’s Impact, Finance Minister Says
SUMMARY: The country’s finance minister said sanctions on Russia were “not cost free for us at home.”

TITLE: Wall Street bonuses jumped 20 percent to a record, but the boom may be short-lived.
SUMMARY: Bankers in New York City’s securities industry got an average bonus of $257,500 last year, the state’s comptroller estimated.

TITLE: Putin to Charge in Rubles for Russian Oil Purchases by ‘Unfriendly Countries’
SUMMARY: The comments by the Russian president are an effort to prop up the value of the ruble, which has plunged because of sanctions.

TITLE: Nestle Suspends KitKat and Nesquik Sales in Russia After Criticism From Zelensky
SUMMARY: The consumer giant said it did not expect to make a profit in the country “for the foreseeable future.”

TITLE: Measuring the Risk of Recession
SUMMARY: The markets are sending mixed signals.

TITLE: Owners of For-Profit Schools Must Pay if the Colleges Close, Education Department Says
SUMMARY: A new rule will put the companies that own some for-profit schools on the hook if their campuses defraud students or close their doors.

TITLE: The Morphe Beauty Saga Isn’t Pretty
SUMMARY: What happens when a beauty brand’s collaborators become too controversial, makeup trends change, and Gen Zers flock to TikTok?

TITLE: Online Brands Try a Traditional Marketing Strategy: Physical Stores
SUMMARY: As digital advertising costs rise, more direct-to-consumer retailers are opening shops, leasing turnkey options or securing short-term spaces in other stores.

TITLE: Rival Sept. 11 Victims Near Potential Deal to Divide Afghan Central Bank Assets
SUMMARY: But another group opposes it. A court has not yet decided whether $3.5 billion in Afghan central bank funds can be used to pay Taliban debts.

TITLE: Biden Plans Sanctions on Russian Lawmakers as He Heads to Europe
SUMMARY: A chief goal of the meetings this week is to show that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine will not lead to sniping and disagreement among the United States and its allies.

TITLE: No Survivors Found in China Eastern Plane Crash, Officials Say
SUMMARY: Workers recovered identity cards, cellphones and purses from the crash site. But the plane’s steep plunge suggested there was a “minuscule” chance of any survivors, an expert said.

TITLE: Will War Make Europe’s Switch to Clean Energy Even Harder?
SUMMARY: A wind turbine factory in Denmark and a coal mine in Poland illustrate the painful policy choices after Russia’s aggression in Ukraine added urgency to the transition to greener energy.

TITLE: Bitcoin Miners Want to Recast Themselves as Eco-Friendly
SUMMARY: Facing intense criticism, the crypto mining industry is trying to change the view that its energy-guzzling computers are harmful to the climate.

TITLE: Netflix Lures ‘Bridgerton’ Fans With Live Event: The Queen’s Ball
SUMMARY: A royal ball inspired by the popular Shonda Rhimes show aims to encourage the kind of water-cooler buzz that streaming services have struggled to create.

TITLE: U.S. and Britain Reach Trade Deal on Metals, Whiskey, Jeans and More
SUMMARY: The step, announced as U.S. and British officials met in Baltimore, removed trade barriers erected under former President Donald J. Trump.

TITLE: Virginia Drops Covid Workplace Rules
SUMMARY: The rules required employers to mandate indoor masking in higher-risk areas and to report Covid outbreaks to the state’s Department of Health.

TITLE: When Are Mask Mandates on Airplanes Ending?
SUMMARY: Should mask rules on planes be lifted? Several British airlines have just suspended the requirement, but in the United States, the mandate, to be reviewed next month, remains. Here’s a look at where things stand.

TITLE: Disney Employees Walk Out Amid Furor Over Florida Anti-LGBTQ Bill
SUMMARY: Hoping to avoid controversy, the company initially shied away from taking a public stance on the anti-L.G.B.T.Q. bill. Now, an internal outcry has stretched into its third week.

TITLE: MacKenzie Scott Gives $436 Million to Habitat for Humanity
SUMMARY: The donation is part of an ongoing effort by Ms. Scott to give away her fortune.

TITLE: Chris Madden, Lifestyle Author and Personality, Dies at 73
SUMMARY: An early HGTV host, she lent her name to furniture and housewares lines. In the late 1990s, her book on women’s private sanctuaries touched a nerve.

TITLE: Ukraine War and Pandemic Force Nations to Retreat From Globalization
SUMMARY: Conflicts among the U.S., Russia and China — and endless Covid-19 outbreaks — strain the interdependent economy and Western ideas of post-Cold War stability.

TITLE: Starbucks Store in Seattle Votes to Unionize
SUMMARY: The 9-0 tally was the seventh union victory in the U.S. in a push that began last year.

TITLE: TotalEnergies Will Stop Buying Oil From Russia
SUMMARY: The French company said it had been accused of “complicity in war crimes” for continuing to work in Russia.

TITLE: Justin and Ben Smith Pick Semafor as the Name for Their Media Start-up
SUMMARY: The name, Semafor, a variation on the word “semaphore,” appears in similar form in many languages.

TITLE: Kanye West’s Stormy Relationship With the Grammys Erupts Again
SUMMARY: The musician, nominated for five awards, was told he will not be able to perform at the ceremony on April 3. The decision came after weeks of erratic and troubling public behavior.

TITLE: Tesla Opens Gigafactory Near Berlin, Its First Plant in Europe
SUMMARY: The $7 billion plant will eventually produce half a million S.U.V.s a year, the company said.

TITLE: How Instagram’s Algorithm Change Is Hurting Small Businesses
SUMMARY: Instagram’s choice to prioritize videos over photos creates unforeseen costs for small companies, leaving many owners disheartened.

TITLE: BuzzFeed News Top Editor Mark Schoofs to Leave Ahead of Newsroom Cuts
SUMMARY: Mark Schoofs, the site’s editor in chief, is among the departures. The chief executive said BuzzFeed News would need to “prioritize the areas of coverage our audience connects with the most.”

TITLE: S.E.C. Climate Proposal is ‘Very Significant’ for Business
SUMMARY: The S.E.C. has proposed sweeping new rules on company climate disclosures.

TITLE: China Evergrande Says it Will Delay Its Financial Report
SUMMARY: The news is the latest setback for the hugely indebted Chinese property developer, which fell into default last year.

TITLE: How Native Americans Are Trying to Debug A.I.’s Biases
SUMMARY: Data on Native communities are not at the levels needed for accuracy in A.I.-driven tools. A group is trying to solve that problem.

TITLE: Boeing Faces New Upheaval After Crash of Chinese Airliner
SUMMARY: No fault has been found, but the company, which has been trying to overcome a recent legacy of design and production troubles, is likely to get scrutinized.

TITLE: After China’s Worst Air Crash in Years, a Desperate Hunt for Survivors
SUMMARY: The plane that crashed in a mountainous area of southern China was carrying 132 people, and no survivors have been found so far, a state broadcaster said on Tuesday.

TITLE: Biden Warns Private Sector of Potential Russian Cyberattacks
SUMMARY: The president cited “evolving intelligence” and urged companies to strengthen their defenses immediately.

TITLE: Russia’s Loss of Rocket Launch Business Becomes SpaceX’s Gain
SUMMARY: OneWeb, a British satellite internet company, turned to SpaceX’s rockets after canceling launches with Russia’s Soyuz vehicle over the invasion of Ukraine.

TITLE: Google Settles With Six Employees Who Worked on Unionization Efforts
SUMMARY: Four were dismissed, and two were disciplined. Google has said its actions had nothing to do with trying to combat unionization efforts.
